title: How many words do writers write a day? - Quora

response.answer_text: My wife (also a writer) texted me today that she only wrote 600 words, feeling bummed about it. She usually writes a thousand, minimum, and also has a day job, and usually writes before work. Her text made me laugh. Some of the most productive days I’ve had have been in the 500–700 word range. Not the most productive in terms of word count (those would be in the 3,000–5,000 word range), but in terms of the five or six hundred words I wrote that day. Her process is to burn through a first draft at blistering speed, completing a novel in a few months. When she spent a month just writing two years ago, she started having wrist/forearm problems because of how fast that first draft flew out. Her first draft was very much that, too. We ended up rewriting entire sections of the book, changing major plot lines in the second draft, etc. She’s doing it again right now (today notwithstanding) and I’ve told her that’s fine, but her first draft is also essentially an outline. That’s anything but a criticism. It’s just her process. She has this compelling need to get the first draft done and, while the story may be complete, it’s still like looking at a house that’s been framed but doesn’t have walls yet. She basically flies by the seat of her pants through a skeleton first draft, knowing there’s a lot she’ll need to fill in when she’s done. My process is wildly different. I’ll write a sentence of dialogue and go empty the top half of the dishwasher parsing through the exact wording of the next sentence. I may type a sentence or ten before the next thing I don’t think I’m wording exactly as I want to shows up, and it may take me unloading the rest of the dishwasher and vacuuming half the house, and/or a five-mile run and taking the dogs on a walk, before I’m ready to write another sentence. Her advice would be to shoot for 1,000 words a day. It’s not bad advice, either, especially if you’re just starting to try writing. In fact, I had a minimum of 2,000 words as my goal/expectation when she and I started working together (then collaborating, then falling in love—it’s a long story). Having that kind of goal works for her and (on my current project, anyway) doesn’t work at all for me. What works best for me is defining how much time I’m going to spend writing and keeping track of that time. If it takes me 10 hours to write 1,000 words, that’s fine as long as my primary focus is on the next word or sentence for those 10 hours. If I write 1,000 words in an hour, I’m still on the clock for the next five, so I should keep writing.

There’s no set amount. Inspiration comes on different days and sometimes, not for days or weeks or month at a time. That being said, I am an employed writer (a content marketer) so I write every single day. I write between 1,000 and 2,500 words on average. Not because I necessarily want to, but because I have to and I get paid to and businesses count on me to. Outside my profession—say on weekends or on holidays—I force myself to write at least a journal entry per day. The journal entry can be as short as three things I am grateful for to pages of thoughts. I think what’s more important than how many words per day is just getting into the habit of writing daily. Forget length. Don’t stress about quality. Just create a writing habit and stick to it.
